section.title: Detailed Description
section.para: Functions to provide thread synchronization primitives.

section.title: SDL_MUTEX_MAXWAIT
section.para: This is the timeout value which corresponds to never time out.

section.title: SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT
section.para: Synchronization functions which can time out return this value if they time out.

section.title: SDL_CondBroadcast()
section.para: Restart all threads that are waiting on the condition variable.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 on success or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CondSignal()
section.para: Restart one of the threads that are waiting on the condition variable.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 on success or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CondWait()

para.computeroutput: DECLSPEC int SDLCALL SDL_CondWait (SDL_cond * cond, SDL_mutex * mutex)

section.para: Wait until a condition variable is signaled.

This function unlocks the specified mutex and waits for another thread to call SDL_CondSignal() or SDL_CondBroadcast() on the condition variable cond. Once the condition variable is signaled, the mutex is re-locked and the function returns.
The mutex must be locked before calling this function.
This function is the equivalent of calling SDL_CondWaitTimeout() with a time length of SDL_MUTEX_MAXWAIT.

entry.para: the condition variable to wait on
the mutex used to coordinate thread access

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 when it is signaled or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CondWaitTimeout()

para.computeroutput: DECLSPEC int SDLCALL SDL_CondWaitTimeout (SDL_cond * cond, SDL_mutex * mutex, Uint32 ms)

section.para: Wait until a condition variable is signaled or a certain time has passed.

This function unlocks the specified mutex and waits for another thread to call SDL_CondSignal() or SDL_CondBroadcast() on the condition variable cond, or for the specified time to elapse. Once the condition variable is signaled or the time elapsed, the mutex is re-locked and the function returns.
The mutex must be locked before calling this function.

entry.para: the condition variable to wait on
the mutex used to coordinate thread access
the maximum time to wait, in milliseconds, or SDL_MUTEX_MAXWAIT to wait indefinitely

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 if the condition variable is signaled, SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT if the condition is not signaled in the allotted time, or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CreateCond()
section.para: Create a condition variable.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: a new condition variable or NULL on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CreateMutex()
section.para: Create a new mutex.
All newly-created mutexes begin in the unlocked state.
Calls to SDL_LockMutex() will not return while the mutex is locked by another thread. See SDL_TryLockMutex() to attempt to lock without blocking.
SDL mutexes are reentrant.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: the initialized and unlocked mutex or NULL on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_CreateSemaphore()
section.para: Create a semaphore.

This function creates a new semaphore and initializes it with the value initial_value. Each wait operation on the semaphore will atomically decrement the semaphore value and potentially block if the semaphore value is 0. Each post operation will atomically increment the semaphore value and wake waiting threads and allow them to retry the wait operation.

entry.para: the starting value of the semaphore

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: a new semaphore or NULL on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_DestroyCond()
section.para: Destroy a condition variable.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_DestroyMutex()
section.para: Destroy a mutex created with SDL_CreateMutex().

This function must be called on any mutex that is no longer needed. Failure to destroy a mutex will result in a system memory or resource leak. While it is safe to destroy a mutex that is unlocked, it is not safe to attempt to destroy a locked mutex, and may result in undefined behavior depending on the platform.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_DestroySemaphore()
section.para: Destroy a semaphore.
It is not safe to destroy a semaphore if there are threads currently waiting on it.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_LockMutex()
section.para: Lock the mutex.

This will block until the mutex is available, which is to say it is in the unlocked state and the OS has chosen the caller as the next thread to lock it. Of all threads waiting to lock the mutex, only one may do so at a time.

It is legal for the owning thread to lock an already-locked mutex. It must unlock it the same number of times before it is actually made available for other threads in the system (this is known as a "recursive mutex").

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0, or -1 on error.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_SemPost()
section.para: Atomically increment a semaphore's value and wake waiting threads.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 on success or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_SemTryWait()
section.para: See if a semaphore has a positive value and decrement it if it does.

This function checks to see if the semaphore pointed to by sem has a positive value and atomically decrements the semaphore value if it does. If the semaphore doesn't have a positive value, the function immediately returns SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 if the wait succeeds, SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT if the wait would block, or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_SemValue()
section.para: Get the current value of a semaphore.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: the current value of the semaphore.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_SemWait()
section.para: Wait until a semaphore has a positive value and then decrements it.

This function suspends the calling thread until either the semaphore pointed to by sem has a positive value or the call is interrupted by a signal or error. If the call is successful it will atomically decrement the semaphore value.
This function is the equivalent of calling SDL_SemWaitTimeout() with a time length of SDL_MUTEX_MAXWAIT.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 on success or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_SemWaitTimeout()

para.computeroutput: DECLSPEC int SDLCALL SDL_SemWaitTimeout (SDL_sem * sem, Uint32 ms)

section.para: Wait until a semaphore has a positive value and then decrements it.

This function suspends the calling thread until either the semaphore pointed to by sem has a positive value, the call is interrupted by a signal or error, or the specified time has elapsed. If the call is successful it will atomically decrement the semaphore value.

entry.para: the length of the timeout, in milliseconds

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0 if the wait succeeds, SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT if the wait does not succeed in the allotted time, or a negative error code on failure; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_TryLockMutex()
section.para: Try to lock a mutex without blocking.
This works just like SDL_LockMutex(), but if the mutex is not available, this function returns SDL_MUTEX_TIMEOUT immediately.
This technique is useful if you need exclusive access to a resource but don't want to wait for it, and will return to it to try again later.

entry.para: the mutex to try to lock

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0, SDL_MUTEX_TIMEDOUT, or -1 on error; call SDL_GetError() for more information.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.

section.title: SDL_UnlockMutex()
section.para: Unlock the mutex.

It is legal for the owning thread to lock an already-locked mutex. It must unlock it the same number of times before it is actually made available for other threads in the system (this is known as a "recursive mutex").
It is an error to unlock a mutex that has not been locked by the current thread, and doing so results in undefined behavior.
It is also an error to unlock a mutex that isn't locked at all.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 0, or -1 on error.

formalpara.title: Since
formalpara.para: This function is available since SDL 2.0.0.
